[[Columbia University]] }} '''Royal Meeker''' (February 23, 1873 – August 16, 1953[http://www.rootsweb.com/~pasusque/hill.htm Descendants of Michael Hill (source for birth/death dates)]) was an [[United states|American]] economist, born at [[Quaker Lake, Pennsylvania|Quaker Lake]], [[Susquehanna County]], [[Pennsylvania]]. He graduated from [[Iowa State College]] in 1898, then studied with [[E.R.A. Seligman]] at [[Columbia University|Columbia]] (Ph.D., 1906) and for a year at the [[University of Leipzig]] (1903–04). His dissertation was entitled ''History of Shipping Subsidies'' (1905). From 1906 to 1913, Meeker was a professor of history, economics, and political science at [[Ursinus College]], [[Collegeville, Pennsylvania]] and a preceptor and professor of economics at [[Princeton University|Princeton]]. He knew [[Woodrow Wilson]], then the president of Princeton, and they served together on New Jersey political boards. Both were associated with the [[Progressivism|Progressive]] movement for an active role for government.Goldberg, Joseph P., and William T. Moye. 1985. ''[http://www.bls.gov/opub/blsfirsthundredyears/ First hundred years of the Bureau of Labor Statistics]''. Bureau of Labor Statistics Bulletin 2235. U.S. Government Printing Office. ISBN 0-935043-01-2. pp. 81-83. President [[Woodrow Wilson|Wilson]] appointed Meeker Commissioner of Labor Statistics in 1913. As the commissioner of the [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]], Meeker managed special economic studies during World War I and began its regular publication, the ''[[Monthly Labor Review]]'', in 1915.Goldberg and Moye, p. 110. Meeker resigned from the administration in June 1920 to take up the opportunity to help organize the new [[International Labor Organization]], where he was the Chief of the Scientific Division from 1920 to 1923.Goldberg and Moye, p. 113. Meeker served as Pennsylvania Secretary of Labor and Industry from 1923–24, and later joined the faculty of [[Carleton College]] (1926–27) and [[Yale University]] (1930-36, perhaps longer). He was Director of Research of the Connecticut Department of Labor (1941–46).Goldberg and Moye, p. 113. He died in [[New Haven, Connecticut]] in 1953. Meeker advocated progressive reforms, including national health insurance,[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=LskaPobqNyEC&pg=PA99&lpg=PA99&dq=Royal+Meeker+health+insurance Goldberg and Moye, p. 99] child labor restrictions combined with strong, State-controlled schools, workmen's compensation, and a nationwide system of public employment offices.http://www.bls.gov/bls/history/commissioners/meeker.htm. Meeker also held controversial views associated with [[eugenics]] that now seem harsh, writing that “It is much better to enact a minimum-wage law even if it deprives these unfortunates of work… better that the state should support the inefficient wholly and prevent the multiplication of the breed than subsidize incompetence and unthrift, enabling them to bring forth more of their kind.” ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{Persondata | NAME = Meeker, Royal | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American economist and official | DATE OF BIRTH = February 23, 1873 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Quaker Lake, Pennsylvania, US | DATE OF DEATH = August 16, 1953 | PLACE OF DEATH = New Haven, Connecticut, US }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Meeker, Royal}} [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:1873 births]] [[Category:1953 deaths]] [[Category:American economists]] [[Category:American historians]] [[Category:American statisticians]] [[Category:Princeton University faculty]] [[Category:Yale University faculty]] [[Category:Bureau of Labor Statistics]]
